stem: You receive a message that says, “Your package is stuck; pay a small fee now to release it.” A green “Pay Fee” button flashes and a timer shows “03:59” counting down.

choices.A: Click and pay before time is up
choices.B: Search your order history first to see if anything is delayed
choices.C: Forward the message to friends so they can avoid delays too
choices.D: Reply asking the sender why there’s a fee

stem: You get a text “Congrats! You won two phones. Claim within 15 minutes.” The link looks like “prizes-today.co.”

choices.B: Open link to claim the prize
choices.A: Delete the text and move on
choices.C: Reply STOP so they remove you
choices.D: Share link on social media for friends

stem: A pop-up on a news site shouts, “Your device is infected! Tap to clean now.” It vibrates your screen to warn you.

choices.A: Tap so the virus is removed
choices.D: Close the pop-up and update your real antivirus instead
choices.C: Restart the device and ignore future alerts
choices.B: Lower screen brightness to stop the vibration

stem: A stranger in a game chat offers free premium coins if you log in on their promo page to sync rewards.

choices.A: Log in to grab the coins
choices.D: Ask game support if the promo is real first
choices.C: Share the promo link with clan members
choices.B: Use a guest account on the promo page

stem: Your class WhatsApp group suddenly posts “Free study guides, download here” from an unknown number.

choices.B: Ask an admin if the download is safe
choices.D: Delete group chat to stay safe

stem: A café table tent shows “Rate us, win a free dessert” with a short link you must type into your browser.

choices.A: Type link and fill survey on the spot
choices.C: Ask a server to confirm the offer is real
choices.B: Take tent home and decide later
choices.D: Use someone else’s phone to open link first

stem: Your sister sent you an email saying “Need help; send money to this wallet.” What would you do?

choices.A: Send small amount to be safe
choices.C: Call her on the phone before doing anything
choices.B: Forward email to parents for advice
choices.D: Reply asking more questions over email

stem: A company IT message pops up on your work chat: “Servers down, log in on this backup site now to keep access.”

choices.B: Click fast so you don’t lose files
choices.A: Compare the link with the real company website address first
choices.C: Copy link into a document for later

stem: You spot a QR sticker over the official parking meter code that promises 50 % off parking today only.

choices.C: Take a photo for your blog then scan

stem: During an online marketplace chat, a buyer sends a link to continue with the sale process in another chat application.

choices.B: Open link so sale can continue
choices.A: Suggest you both continue using the marketplace’s own chat only
choices.D: Ask the buyer to video call on the same link

stem: Your hotel room TV shows a welcome screen urging guests to “connect phone for free movie streaming” via a strange web address that expires in five minutes.

choices.C: Call front desk to confirm before connecting
choices.D: Use someone else’s room TV instead

stem: A popular influencer’s giveaway asks followers to fill a form with address and ID photo to pass prize taxes.

choices.B: Check the influencer’s official page for giveaway details before sharing
choices.C: Post your own giveaway to distract scammers
choices.D: Ask friends if they already filled it

stem: A bank site tells you your card is locked and shows a padlock animation. It asks for card number, PIN, and the three digits on the back.

choices.A: Enter details—the padlock shows it’s secure
choices.C: Leave the page and phone the bank using the official phone number
choices.B: Enter wrong details first to test it
choices.D: Refresh page to see if lock goes away

stem: On social media, an ad for cheap flight tickets directs to a page that loads only after you allow browser notifications.

choices.D: Search for the offer on the airline’s real site first
choices.B: Share the ad to friends before checking

stem: An unexpected calendar invite titled “Salary Adjustment Meeting” contains a link “read documents before meeting.” The organizer email ends with “-hr-team@consult-mail.com.”

choices.B: Accept invite and open link immediately
choices.A: Open your company directory to see if that email belongs to HR
choices.C: Forward invite to entire team to warn them
choices.D: Decline invite but keep the link for later

stem: A loyalty-points email urges you to transfer points to a friend within 2 hours or they expire, requiring you to sign in through a page that asks for both password and security answers.

choices.A: Sign in and move points fast
choices.B: Log in through the retailer’s own app instead of the email link
choices.C: Reply asking them to extend deadline

stem: A podcast guest claims anyone can double their money by wiring funds to a program and sharing the receipt on a private channel to trigger the return.

choices.B: Research the guest’s background independently before acting
choices.D: Sign up friends so you all earn

stem: Your work printer displays “Firmware update available—scan code with phone to install.”

choices.D: Report the message to tech support before scanning anything
choices.C: Turn printer off and on hoping message clears
choices.B: Scan but stay on Wi-Fi instead of mobile data

stem: You receive a Facebook message from a cousin saying they lost their wallet while abroad and need you to send money urgently to a digital wallet. In 1–3 sentences, explain how you would check if the request is real and what actions you would (or would not) take.

rubric.point: Contact cousin through another trusted method first (call/video)
Avoid sending money until identity is confirmed
Consider reporting the message to the platform

stem: A restaurant table has a laminated QR code saying “leave a tip and get a surprise gift.” Describe, in a few sentences, the steps you would follow before scanning and entering any payment details.

rubric.point: Check with staff that the code belongs to the restaurant
Look at the web address after scanning before paying
Decide not to enter card data on pages you don’t fully trust

stem: An email claims to be the school principal announcing new safety rules. It asks parents to log in using their parent-portal password on a linked page. Explain the safest way you would handle this email.

rubric.point: Access the parent portal through the usual bookmarked link, not the email
Verify with the school office through phone or in-person
Report or delete the suspicious email
